Language.Name: adjective-related
Language.Description: Morphosyntactic features that are generally associated with adjectives and adjective phrases.

Language.Name: article-related
Language.Description: Morphosyntactic features that are generally associated with articles or determiners.

Language.Name: demonstrative
Language.Description: A demonstrative article or determiner is a demonstrative that appears with a head noun in a noun phrase. For example, the word that in the sentence I like that book.

Language.Name: demonstrative
Language.Description: A demonstrative pronoun is a demonstrative that stands alone in a noun phrase. For example, the word that in the sentence I like that.

Language.Name: noun-related
Language.Description: Morphosyntactic features that are generally associated with nouns and noun phrases.

Language.Name: definiteness
Language.Description: Definiteness is a category concerned with the grammaticalization of identifiability and nonidentifiability of referents on the part of a speaker or addressee.

Language.Name: definite identifiability
Language.Description: Definite identifiability is a kind of definiteness which indicates that an expression's referent(s) is in some way identifiable to both speaker and addressee.The referent is identifiable because of a shared knowledge or situation, including a previous mention of the referent.

Language.Name: generic term
Language.Description: A generic term is a noun or noun phrase that refers to (1) a whole class, or (2) any member of a class as a representative of its class.

Language.Name: indefiniteness
Language.Description: Indefiniteness is a kind of definiteness indicating that the referent(s) of an expression are not presumed to be identifiable. The referent is not identifiable because of a lack of shared knowledge or situation, including no previous mention of the referent.

Language.Name: nonspecificity
Language.Description: Nonspecificity is a kind of definiteness, expressed by an interpretation of or grammatical marking on a noun or noun phrase, indicating that the speaker presumably does not know the identity of the referent(s).

Language.Name: specificity
Language.Description: Specificity is a kind of definiteness, expressed by the interpretation of or grammatical marking on a noun or noun phrase, indicating that the speaker presumably knows the identity of the referent(s).

Language.Name: semantic role
Language.Description: A semantic role is the underlying relationship that a participant has with the main verb in a clause.

Language.Name: accompaniment
Language.Description: Accompaniment is the semantic role of a thing that participates in close association with an agent, causer, or affected in an event.

Language.Name: agent
Language.Description: Agent is the semantic role of a person or thing who is the doer of an event.

Language.Name: beneficiary
Language.Description: A beneficiary is the semantic role of a referent which is advantaged or disadvantaged by an event.

Language.Name: causer
Language.Description: Causer is the semantic role of the referent which instigates an event rather than actually doing it.

Language.Name: counter-agent
Language.Description: A counteragent is the semantic role of a force or resistance against which an action is carried out.

Language.Name: dative
Language.Description: Dative is the semantic role of a referent that is conscious of being affected by the state or action identified by the verb.Also known as: Recipient

Language.Name: experiencer
Language.Description: Experiencer is the semantic role of an entity (or referent) which the effect of an action.

Language.Name: factitive
Language.Description: Factitive is the semantic role of an referent that results from the action or state identified by a verb.

Language.Name: goal
Language.Description: Goal is the semantic role of

Language.Name: instrument
Language.Description: Instrument is the semantic role of an inanimate thing that an agent uses to implement an event. It is the stimulus or immediate physical cause of an event.

Language.Name: locative
Language.Description: Locative is a semantic role which identifies the location or spatial orientation of a state or action. A locative semantic role does not imply motion to, from, or across the location.

Language.Name: manner
Language.Description: Manner is a semantic role that notes how the action, experience, or process of an event is carried out.

Language.Name: measure
Language.Description: Measure is a semantic role which notes the quantification of an event.

Language.Name: path
Language.Description: Path is the semantic role describing the locale(s) transversed in motion or propulsion predications.

Language.Name: patient
Language.Description: Patient is a semantic role that is usually the surface object of the verb in a sentence.

Language.Name: range
Language.Description: Range is the semantic role of the entity that completes, is a product of, or further specifies an event.

Language.Name: result
Language.Description: A result is a semantic role that refers to that which is produced by an event. This role is usually encoded as the surface object of a sentence.

Language.Name: source
Language.Description: Source is the semantic role of the following referents:

Language.Name: time
Language.Description: Time is the semantic role of the temporal placement of an event.

Language.Name: verb-related
Language.Description: Morphosyntactic features that are generally associated with verbs and verb phrases.

Language.Name: aspect
Language.Description: Aspect is a grammatical category associated with verbs that expresses a temporal view of the event or state expressed by the verb.

Language.Name: atelic aspect
Language.Description: A term used in the grammatical analysis of aspect, to refer to an event where the activity has no clear terminal point. They contrast with telic verbs.

Language.Name: attenuative aspect
Language.Description: A term sometimes used in grammar and semantics, referring to a reduced quality or quantity of the state or activity expressed by the verb ('a little', 'less'). In some languages (e.g., Hungarian) the contrast is a formal part of the aspect system.

Language.Name: cessative aspect
Language.Description: Cessative aspect is aspect that expresses the cessation of an event or state.

Language.Name: continuous aspect
Language.Description: Continuous aspect is an imperfective aspect that expresses an ongoing, but not habitual, occurrence of the state or event expressed by the verb.

Language.Name: distributive aspect
Language.Description: Distributive aspect is an iterative aspect which expresses that an event is applied to members of a group one after another. These members are typically the referents named by (1) the subject of an intransitive verb, or (2) the object of a transitive verb.

Language.Name: durative aspect
Language.Description: Used in grammatical analysis of aspect, to refer to an event involving a period of time (cf. 'continuous', 'progressive'); it contrasts with 'non-durative' or 'punctual'.

Language.Name: frequentative aspect
Language.Description: Used in the grammatical classification of verbs to refer to the expression of repeated action. In some languages (e.g. Russian) the class may be marked morphologically, but in English the meaning is normally expressed through adverbials of frequency, e.g. again, regularly, often.

Language.Name: habitual aspect
Language.Description: Habitual aspect is an imperfective aspect that expresses the occurrence of an event or state as characteristic of a period of time.

Language.Name: imperfective aspect
Language.Description: Imperfective aspect is an aspect that expresses an event or state, with respect to its internal structure, instead of expressing it as a simple whole.

Language.Name: inceptive aspect
Language.Description: Used to refer to a type of aspectual relationship in which the beginning of an action is specified. Same as 'inchoative'.

Language.Name: inchoative aspect
Language.Description: Inchoative aspect is an aspect that expresses the beginning of an event or state.

Language.Name: iterative aspect
Language.Description: Iterative aspect is an aspect that expresses the repetition of an event or state.

Language.Name: perfective aspect
Language.Description: Perfective aspect is an aspect that expresses a temporal view of an event or state as a simple whole, apart from the consideration of the internal structure of the time in which it occurs.

Language.Name: progressive aspect
Language.Description: Progressive aspect is a continuous aspect that expresses processes, not states.

Language.Name: punctual aspect
Language.Description: Used in analysis of aspect to refer to a momentary event, thought of as having no temporal duration; it thus contrasts with durative or continuous events, where a period of time is involved.

Language.Name: telic aspect
Language.Description: A term used in grammatical analysis of aspect, to refer to an event where the activity has a clear terminal point. These verbs contrast with atelic verbs.

Language.Name: mood and modality
Language.Description: Mood is one of a set of distinctive forms that are used to signal modality. Modality is a facet of illocutionary force, signaled by grammatical devices (that is, moods), that expresses (1) the illocutionary point or general intent of a speaker, or (2) a speaker's degree of commitment to the expressed proposition's believability, obligatoriness, desirability, or reality.

Language.Name: alethic modality
Language.Description: Alethic modality is modality that connotes the speaker's estimation of the logical necessity or possibility of the proposition expressed by his utterance.

Language.Name: assumptive mood
Language.Description: Assumptive mood is an epistemic mode that signals the speaker's belief that his statement is based on facts about what is usually the case in such circumstances.

Language.Name: auditory evidential
Language.Description: An auditory evidential is a nonvisual evidential that signals that the speaker's evidence for the truth of his statement is based on what he has heard.

Language.Name: commissive modality
Language.Description: Commissive modality is a deontic modality that connotes the speaker's expressed commitment, as a promise or threat, to bring about the proposition expressed by the utterance.

Language.Name: declarative mood
Language.Description: Declarative mood is an epistemic mood that signals that the proposition expressed by a speaker's utterance is offered as an unqualified statement of fact.

Language.Name: deductive mood
Language.Description: Deductive mood is an epistemic mood that signals that the speaker judges from other facts that the proposition expressed by his utterance is probably true.

Language.Name: deliberative mood
Language.Description: Deliberative mood is a directive mood which signals the speaker's request for instruction from the addressee as to whether to do the proposition expressed in the utterance.

Language.Name: deontic modality
Language.Description: Deontic modality is modality that connotes the speaker's (1) degree of requirement of, (2) desire for, or (3) commitment to the realization of the proposition expressed by the utterance.

Language.Name: directive modality
Language.Description: Directive modality is a deontic modality that connotes the speaker's degree of requirement of conformity to the proposition expressed by an utterance.

Language.Name: dubitative mood
Language.Description: Dubitative mood is an epistemic mood which signals a speaker's reservation about the accuracy of his or her statement.

Language.Name: epistemic modality
Language.Description: Epistemic modality is a modality that connotes how much certainty or evidence a speaker has for the proposition expressed by his or her utterance.

Language.Name: evidentiality modality
Language.Description: Evidentiality is an epistemic modality that connotes the speaker's assessment of the evidence for his or her statement. An evidential is a form, such as a verbal affix, that is a grammatical expression of evidentiality.

Language.Name: hypothetical mood
Language.Description: Hypothetical mood is an epistemic mood that signals that the speaker evaluates a proposition as counterfactual, but otherwise possible.

Language.Name: immediate imperative mood
Language.Description: Immediate imperative mood is an imperative mood that signals that the command or request is to be carried out right away.

Language.Name: imperative mood
Language.Description: Imperative mood is mood that signals directive modality, especially in commands. Its use may be extended to signal permission.

Language.Name: imprecative mood
Language.Description: Imprecative mood is a volitive mood that signals the speaker's wish that an unfavorable proposition will come about.

Citations.Citation: Lewis, G.L. 1967:115, cited by Sadock and Zwicky 1985:163

Language.Name: interrogative mood
Language.Description: An interrogative mood is an epistemic mood that signals that the speaker wishes to elicit information concerning the content of his or her utterance from the addressee.

Language.Name: irrealis modality
Language.Description: Irrealis modality is a modality that connotes that the proposition with which it is associated is nonactual or nonfactual.

Language.Name: judgment modality
Language.Description: Judgment modality is an epistemic modality that connotes the speaker's (1) strength of inference, or (2) degree of confidence in the reality of the proposition expressed by his or her utterance.

Language.Name: jussive mood
Language.Description: Jussive mood is a directive mood that signals a speaker's (1) command, (2) permission, or (3) agreement that the proposition expressed by his or her utterance be brought about.

Language.Name: necessity modality
Language.Description: Necessity is a degree of contingency in modality that (1) in alethic modality connotes logical requirement, (2) in deontic modality connotes obligation, and (3) in epistemic modality connotes certainty.

Language.Name: nonvisual evidential
Language.Description: A nonvisual evidential is a sensory evidential that signals that the speaker's evidence for the truth of his or her statement is derived from a sense other than sight.

Language.Name: obligative mood
Language.Description: Obligative mood is a directive mood that signals the speaker's estimation of the necessity that the proposition expressed in his or her utterance be brought about.

Language.Name: optative mood
Language.Description: Optative mood is a volitive mood that signals wishing or hoping.

Language.Name: permissive mood
Language.Description: Permissive mood is a directive mood that signals the speaker's act of giving permission.

Language.Name: possibility modality
Language.Description: Possibility is a degree of contingency in modality that (1) in alethic modality connotes logical possibility, (2) in deontic modality connotes permission, and (3) in epistemic modality connotes uncertainty or speculation.

Language.Name: precative mood
Language.Description: Precative mood is a directive mood that signals that the utterance is a request.

Language.Name: prohibitive mood
Language.Description: Prohibitive mood is a directive mood that signals a prohibition. It is distinguished by (1) the use of a negated imperative sentence that employs a negative marker distinct from that used in declarative sentences, or (2) a verb form different from that of the imperative.

Language.Name: quotative evidential
Language.Description: A quotative evidential is an evidential that signals that someone else is the source of the statement made.

Language.Name: realis modality
Language.Description: Realis modality is a modality that connotes the factuality of a proposition.

Language.Name: sensory evidential
Language.Description: A sensory evidential is an evidential signaling that the speaker's evidence for the truth of his or her statement is derived from the speaker's own sensory experience.

Language.Name: speculative mood
Language.Description: Speculative mood is an epistemic mood that signals that the speaker judges from certain facts that the proposition expressed by his or her utterance is possibly true.

Language.Name: subjunctive mood
Language.Description: mood is a mood that typically signals irrealis meanings, such as (1) potentiality, (2) uncertainty, (3) prediction, (4) obligation, and (5) desire. It most typically occurs in a subordinate clause, but may occur outside of one.

Language.Name: visual evidential
Language.Description: A visual evidential is a sensory evidential signaling that the speaker's evidence for the truth of his or her statement is derived from the speaker's own sight.

Language.Name: volitive modality
Language.Description: Volitive modality is a deontic modality that expresses the speaker's attitude of hope, wish, or fear concerning the proposition expressed by the utterance.

Language.Name: polarity
Language.Description: Polarity is a grammatical category that distinguishes affirmative and negative.

Language.Name: switch reference
Language.Description: Switch reference is a grammatical category with the following features: It signals the identity or nonidentity of the referent of an argument of one clause, usually its subject, with an argument of another clause, which is likewise usually the subject. Switch reference functions to avoid ambiguity of reference; for example, it may distinguish between two referents that are third person and that, thus, may not be otherwise distinguished on the verb. It relates clauses, usually adjacent, that may be subordinate or coordinate to one another. It is expressed: (1) usually by inflectional affixes on the verb, (2) sometimes by the same affixes that express subject-verb agreement within the clause, and (3) rarely by a morpheme independent of the verb.

Language.Name: different subject marker
Language.Description: A different subject marker is a marker in the verb morphology of a clause which indicates that the subject of the clause is not the same as the subject of some other clause. The other clause is maybe a following clause, the final clause in a clause chain, or the main clause in a sentence.

Language.Name: same subject marker
Language.Description: A same subject marker is a distinction in the verb morphology of a clause that indicates that the subject is identical to the subject of another clause, such as one of the following: A following clause, the final clause in a clause chain, or the main clause in a sentence.

Language.Name: tense
Language.Description: Tense is a grammatical category, typically marked on the verb, that deictically refers to the time of the event or state denoted by the verb in relation to some other temporal reference point.

Language.Name: absolute tense
Language.Description: Absolute tense is a tense that refers to a time in relation to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: close future tense
Language.Description: Close future tense is a tense that refers to a time shortly after the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: future tense
Language.Description: Future tense is an absolute tense that refers to a time after the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: hesternal past tense
Language.Description: Hesternal past tense is a past tense that refers to a time that is located somewhere in the span beginning with the period defined culturally as "yesterday" and extends back through some period that is considered nonremote.

Language.Name: hodiernal future tense
Language.Description: Hodiernal future tense is a future tense that refers to a time that is located after the moment of utterance within the span culturally defined as "today."

Language.Name: hodiernal past tense
Language.Description: Hodiernal past tense is a past tense that refers to a time as located before the moment of utterance within the span culturally defined as "today."

Language.Name: immediate past tense
Language.Description: Immediate past tense is past tense that refers to a time considered very recent in relation to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: nonfuture tense
Language.Description: Nonfuture tense is an absolute tense that (1) refers to a time at or before the moment of utterance, and (2) contrasts with a future tense.

Language.Name: nonpast tense
Language.Description: Nonpast tense is an absolute tense that (1) refers to a time at or after the moment of utterance, and (2) contrasts with a past tense.

Language.Name: nonrecent past tense
Language.Description: Nonrecent past tense is a past tense that refers to a time before the range of a contrasting recent past tense.

Language.Name: nonremote past tense
Language.Description: Nonremote past tense is a past tense that refers to a time considered not more than a few days ago, in contrast to a remote past tense.

Language.Name: not-yet tense
Language.Description: Not-yet tense is an absolute tense that refers to times at and before the moment of utterance in asserting the present and past nonoccurrence of an event or state. It tends to imply that the event or state is expected to occur in the future. This tense corresponds to the meaning of the English not yet.

Language.Name: past tense
Language.Description: Past tense is an absolute tense that refers to a time before the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: post-hodiernal future tense
Language.Description: Post-hodiernal future tense is a future tense that refers to a time, in relation to the moment of utterance, after the span that is culturally defined as "today."

Language.Name: predictive future tense
Language.Description: Predictive future tense is a future tense, used in predictions, that does not express intention.

Language.Name: prehesternal past tense
Language.Description: Prehesternal past tense is a past tense that refers to a time in some span before that of an opposing hesternal past tense.

Language.Name: prehodiernal past tense
Language.Description: Prehodiernal past tense is a past tense that refers to a time in some span before that of a contrasting hodiernal past tense.

Language.Name: present tense
Language.Description: Present tense is an absolute tense that refers to the moment of utterance. It often refers to events or states that do not merely coincide with the moment of utterance, such as those that are (1) continuous, (2) habitual, or (3) lawlike.

Language.Name: preterit
Language.Description: A preterit, in traditional terminology, is a simple past tense not marked for aspect or modality.

Language.Name: recent past tense
Language.Description: Recent past tense is a past tense that refers to a time, culturally and situationally defined, within the span ranging from yesterday to a week or a few months previous.

Language.Name: remote future tense
Language.Description: Remote future is a future tense that refers to a time that is considered relatively distant. It is characteristically after the span of time culturally defined as "tomorrow."

Language.Name: remote past tense
Language.Description: Remote past tense is a past tense that refers to a time considered more than a few days ago.

Language.Name: still tense
Language.Description: Still tense is an absolute tense carrying the presupposition that an event or state held before the moment of utterance.In positive declarative clauses, still tense asserts that the event or state holds at the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: absolute-relative tense
Language.Description: Absolute-relative tense is a tense (1) that refers to a time in relation to a temporal reference point that, in turn, is referred to in relation to the moment of utterance, (2) in which the time and the reference point are not identical, and (3) the reference point and the moment of utterance are not identical.

Language.Name: future perfect tense
Language.Description: Future perfect tense is an absolute-relative tense that refers to a time located before a contextually determined temporal reference point that must be located in the future relative to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: future-in-future tense
Language.Description: Future-in-future tense is an absolute-relative tense that refers to a time located in the future, relative to a temporal reference point that itself is located in the future relative to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: future-in-past tense
Language.Description: Future-in-past tense is an absolute-relative tense that refers to a time located in the future, relative to a contextually determined temporal reference point that itself must be located in the past relative to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: future-perfect-in-past tense
Language.Description: Future-perfect-in-past tense is an absolute-relative tense that involves three points in time in the past. The tense refers to a time that is in the future, relative to another point in the past, but is in the past relative to a point in its future. All these points in time are in the past relative to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: past perfect tense
Language.Description: Past perfect tense is an absolute-relative tense that refers to a time in the past relative to a reference point, which itself is in the past relative to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: relative tense
Language.Description: Relative tense is a tense that refers to a time in relation to a contextually determined temporal reference point, regardless of the latter's temporal relation to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: relative future tense
Language.Description: Relative future tense is a relative tense that refers to a time located after a contextually determined temporal reference point, regardless of the latter's relation to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: relative nonfuture tense
Language.Description: Relative nonfuture tense is a relative tense that refers to a time simultaneous to, or before, a contextually determined temporal reference point, regardless of the latter's relation to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: relative nonpast tense
Language.Description: Relative nonpast tense is a relative tense that refers to a time simultaneous to, or after, a contextually determined temporal reference point, regardless of the latter's relation to the moment of utterance.

Language.Name: relative past tense
Language.Description: Relative past tense is a relative tense that refers to a time located before that of a contextually determined temporal reference point.

Language.Name: relative present tense
Language.Description: Relative present tense is a relative tense that refers to a time that is simultaneous with some contextually determined temporal reference point.

Language.Name: transitivity
Language.Description: Transitivity is the number of objects a verb requires or takes in a given instance.

Language.Name: ditransitivity
Language.Description: Ditransitivity is a term which describes a verb or clause which takes two objects.

Language.Name: intransitivity
Language.Description: Intransitivity is a term that describes a verb or clause that is unable to take a direct object.

Language.Name: transitive verb
Language.Description: A transitive verb is a verb that takes a direct object.

Language.Name: voice
Language.Description: Voice is a grammatical category that expresses the semantic functions attributed to the referents of a clause. It indicates whether the subject is an (1) actor, (2) patient, or (3) recipient.

Language.Name: active voice
Language.Description: Active voice is a voice that indicates a subject has the semantic function of actor.

Language.Name: antipassive voice
Language.Description: Antipassive voice is a voice in an ergative-absolutive language in which (1) a noun phrase that normally has ergative case instead has absolutive case, (2) a noun phrase that normally has absolutive case is marked as an oblique or an indirect object, and (3) the salience of the normally absolutive noun phrase is, according to some analysts, decreased.

Language.Name: mediopassive voice
Language.Description: Mediopassive voice is a passive voice in which (1) the verb has stative meaning, and (2) the actor is not expressed.

Language.Name: middle voice
Language.Description: Middle voice is a voice that indicates that the subject is the actor and acts (1) upon himself or herself reflexively, or (2) for his or her own benefit. In the case of plural subjects, the actors may, perhaps, act upon each other.

Language.Name: passive voice
Language.Description: Passive voice is a voice that indicates that the subject is the patient or recipient of the action denoted by the verb.

Language.Name: voice/focus in Philippine-type languages
Language.Description: Philippine-type languages (e.g. Tagalog and Cebuano as well as some in Malaysia) have a voice or focus system in which the verb selects the semantic role of the grammatical subject. The verb has an affix which says what the semantic role of the subject is.

Language.Name: actor voice/focus
Language.Description: The subject has the semantic role of actor.

Language.Name: goal voice/focus
Language.Description: The subject has the semantic role of goal or recipient. It is sometimes also referred to as dative voice.

Language.Name: instrumental voice/focus
Language.Description: The subject has the semantic role of instrument.

Language.Name: patient voice/focus
Language.Description: The subject has the semantic role of patient. It is sometimes also referred to as object voice.

Language.Name: case
Language.Description: Case is a grammatical category determined by the syntactic or semantic function of a noun or pronoun.

Language.Name: ablative case
Language.Description: Ablative case is a case that expresses a variety of meanings including instrument, cause, location, source, and time.

Language.Name: absolutive case
Language.Description: Absolutive case is the case of nouns in ergative-absolutive languages that would generally be the subjects of intransitive verbs or the objects of transitive verbs in the translational equivalents of nominative-accusative languages such as English.

Language.Name: accusative case
Language.Description: Accusative case is the case in nominative-accusative languages that marks certain syntactic functions, usually direct objects.

Language.Name: allative case
Language.Description: Allative case is a case that expresses motion to or toward the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: benefactive case
Language.Description: Benefactive case is a case that expresses that the referent of the noun it marks receives the benefit of the situation expressed by the clause.

Language.Name: dative case
Language.Description: Dative case is a case that marks any of the following: (1) Indirect objects (for languages in which they are held to exist); (2) Nouns having the role of (a) recipient (as of things given), (b) beneficiary of an action, or (c) possessor of an item.

Language.Name: ergative case
Language.Description: Ergative case is the case of nouns in ergative-absolutive languages that would generally be the subjects of transitive verbs in the translation equivalents of nominative-accusative languages such as English.

Language.Name: genitive case
Language.Description: Genitive case is a case in which the referent of the marked noun is the possessor of the referent of another noun.

Language.Name: illative case
Language.Description: Illative case is a case that expresses motion into or direction toward the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: instrumental case
Language.Description: Instrumental case is a case indicating that the referent of the noun it marks is the means of the accomplishment of the action expressed by the clause.

Language.Name: locative case
Language.Description: Locative case is a case that expresses location at the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: nominative case
Language.Description: Nominative case is the case that identifies clause subjects in nominative-accusative languages. Nouns used in isolation have this case.

Language.Name: vocative case
Language.Description: Vocative case is a case that marks a noun whose referent is being addressed.

Language.Name: abessive case
Language.Description: Abessive case is a case that expresses the lack or absence of the referent of the noun it marks. It has the meaning of the English preposition without.

Language.Name: causative case
Language.Description: Causative case is a case which expresses that the referent of the noun it marks is the cause of the situation expressed by the clause.

Language.Name: comitative case
Language.Description: Comitative case is a case expressing accompaniment. It carries the meaning "with" or "accompanied by."

Language.Name: delative case
Language.Description: Delative case is a case which expresses motion downward from the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: elative case
Language.Description: Elative case is a case expressing motion out of or away from the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: equative case
Language.Description: Equative case is a case that expresses likeness or identity to the referent of the noun it marks. It can have meaning, such as English "as," "like," and "in the capacity of."

Language.Name: essive case
Language.Description: Essive case is a case that expresses the temporary state of the referent specified by a noun. The case has the meaning of (1) while, and (2) in the capacity of.

Language.Name: inessive case
Language.Description: Inessive case is a case that expresses a location within the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: lative case
Language.Description: Lative case is a case that expresses motion (1) up to the location of, or (2) as far as the referent of the noun it marks.

Citations.Citation: Pei and Gaynor 1954:121, Gove, et al. 1966:1277

Language.Name: partitive case
Language.Description: Partitive case is a case that expresses the partial nature of the referent of the noun it marks, as opposed to expressing the whole unit or class of which the referent is a part. This case may be found in items such as the following: (1) Existential clauses, (2) Nouns that are accompanied by numerals or units of measure, or (3) Predications of material from which something is made. It often has a meaning similar to the English word "some."

Language.Name: prolative case
Language.Description: Prolative case is a case that expresses motion along or by the referent of the noun it marks.

Language.Name: superessive case
Language.Description: Superessive case is a case that expresses location on the referent of the noun it marks. It has the meaning of "on" or "upon."

Language.Name: translative case
Language.Description: Translative case is a case indicating that the referent of the noun, or the quality of the adjective, that it marks is the result of a process of change.

Language.Name: person
Language.Description: Person deixis is deictic reference to the participant role of a referent, such as the speaker, the addressee, and referents which are neither speaker nor addressee.

Language.Name: first person
Language.Description: First person deixis is deictic reference that refers to the speaker, or both the speaker and referents grouped with the speaker.

Language.Name: first person exclusive
Language.Description: Exclusive first person deixis is deixis that refers to a group not including the addressee(s).

Language.Name: first person inclusive
Language.Description: Inclusive first person deixis is deixis that refers to a group including the addressee(s).

Language.Name: second person
Language.Description: Second person deixis is deictic reference to a person or persons identified as addressee.

Language.Name: third person
Language.Description: Third person deixis is deictic reference to a referent(s) not identified as the speaker or addressee.

Language.Name: obviative person
Language.Description: Obviative person deixis is third person deixis that distinguishes a less important referent in the present stage of the discourse from a referent that is more important.

Language.Name: proximate person
Language.Description: Proximate person deixis is a third person deixis that distinguishes a referent that is more important at the present stage of the discourse from a referent that is less important.

Language.Name: gender
Language.Description: Grammatical gender is a noun class system, composed of two or three classes, whose nouns that have human male and female referents tend to be in separate classes. Other nouns that are classified in the same way in the language may not be classed by any correlation with natural sex distinctions.

Language.Name: masculine gender
Language.Description: Masculine gender is a grammatical gender that (1) marks nouns having human or animal male referents, and (2) often marks nouns having referents that do not have distinctions of sex.

Language.Name: feminine gender
Language.Description: Feminine gender is a grammatical gender that (1) marks nouns that have human or animal female referents, and (2) often marks nouns that have referents that do not carry distinctions of sex.

Language.Name: neuter gender
Language.Description: Neuter gender is a grammatical gender that (1) includes those nouns having referents which do not have distinctions of sex, and (2) often includes some which do have a natural sex distinction.

Language.Name: number
Language.Description: Number is a grammatical category of nouns, pronouns, and verb agreement that expresses count distinctions (such as "one" or "more than one"). The count distinctions typically, but not always, correspond to the actual count of the referents of the marked noun or pronoun.

Language.Name: singular number
Language.Description: Singular number is number that refers to one member of a designated class.

Language.Name: plural number
Language.Description: Plural number is number that expresses reference to a quantity greater than that expressed by the largest specific number category in a language, such as "more than one" in English, and "more than two" in some other languages.

Language.Name: dual number
Language.Description: Dual number is number which refers to two members of the class identified by the noun.

Language.Name: trial number
Language.Description: A trial number is a number that refers to three members of the designated class.

Language.Name: paucal number
Language.Description: few

Language.Name: noun class
Language.Description: A noun class system is a grammatical system that some languages use to overtly categorize nouns. Noun classes (1) are often based, at least in part, on characteristics (such as gender, animacy, shape) of the referents of some of the nouns in each class, and (2) are distinguished (a) by an affix on the noun or by a clitic or word in the noun phrase, and (b) by agreement affixes on noun phrase constituents and on the verb.

Language.Name: animate class
Language.Description: An animate class is a category of nouns having human or animal referents.

Language.Name: human class
Language.Description: A human class is a noun class that has human referents.

Language.Name: inanimate class
Language.Description: An inanimate class is a category of nouns that do not have human or animal referents.

Language.Name: Bantu noun class
Language.Description: Noun classes for Bantu languages
